description:
Unfortunately, there is no real scientific species known as "Human lung-associated brisavirus II". This appears to be a made-up name, as I could not find any credible references to a virus by this name in scientific literature or databases.

Viruses are typically named according to established taxonomic classification systems, often based on their genetic structure, host organisms, and other well-defined characteristics. Without more specific information about the properties and origins of this hypothetical virus, I cannot provide a meaningful scientific description.

In general, a short scientific description of a real virus species would include details such as:

- Taxonomic classification (family, genus, species)
- Viral genome type (e.g. single-stranded RNA, double-stranded DNA)
- Primary host organism(s)
- Tissue/organ tropism (e.g. lung, liver, nervous system)
- Known transmission routes
- Unique structural or functional features
- Associated diseases or clinical manifestations

However, without a real virus to describe, I cannot provide a substantive scientific characterization. Please let me know if you have any other questions about real, well-established virus species.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species
